explanation:
lfs_bd_cmp: Called directly from lfs_dir_find_match. MISRA requires that the behaviour of a for-loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement, so you must inspect lfs_bd_cmp for any for loops (and whether they obey the three-clause/one-counter constraints).

lfs_bd_read: Called by lfs_bd_cmp (per the static call graph). To fully verify lfs_bd_cmp you must also inspect lfs_bd_read for for-loops and their well-formedness.

lfs_min: Called in lfs_dir_find_match and inside lfs_bd_cmp. Although likely trivial, it must be checked to ensure it does not contain any for-loops (or other side effects) that would affect compliance with the MISRA for-loop requirements.

lfs_tag_size: Called in lfs_dir_find_match to compute sizes. It must be checked to ensure it contains no for-loops (or side effects) that would be part of the called-function behaviour considered by MISRA.

Note: These are the direct callees (and callee of a callee) shown in the provided static call graph. To complete the MISRA for-loop analysis you will need the full definitions/bodies of these symbols (and then recursively any further callees discovered in their bodies) so you can examine any for statements they contain and verify the three clauses and single-counter constraints.
